title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw: This looks good! I see you've set the default alpha low. I strongly agree with this; I hate when the boxes are drawn in full white. The outline should be deep in the background. I think setting the default low will help reduce the number of renders where the box outshines the data.
content.html: This looks good! I see you've set the default alpha low. I strongly agree with this; I hate when the boxes are drawn in full white. The outline should be deep in the background. I think setting the default low will help reduce the number of renders where the box outshines the data.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw:
Thanks!  These changesets were lying around from a long time ago and just needed some touchups.  I'm currently in a layover right now so comments might not make it before I have to fly.  Just for reference, these were shown off in irc:

```
#!python

im = cam.snapshot()
cam.draw_domain(im)
```
http://i.imgur.com/VwUcRGE.png

```
#!python

im = cam.snapshot()
cam.draw_grids(im, alpha=0.5)
```
http://i.imgur.com/U4iT2jC.jpg

content.raw: This is some great functionality.  Thanks for adding this, Sam!  My only comment besides the handful I left in the code is that we probably want (as @chummels noted) docstrings in the format of `doc/docstring_example.txt`.  Very nice!

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw:
At the risk of making this cool new work that Sam has done into a guinea pig, I would also argue that in addition to adding some docstrings, now might be a good time to add a little recipe to the cookbook or the main docs on how to use this great functionality.  I don't want to make a bunch of extra work here, but having appropriate documentation in the docs for new functionality seems to be a problem with yt in general, and this seems to be the only obvious time when it can be added, while it is fresh in the developer's mind.  Again, I don't want to raise the effort required to contribute, but the alternative is out-of-date documentation...

Thoughts?
content.html:
At the risk of making this cool new work that Sam has done into a guinea pig, I would also argue that in addition to adding some docstrings, now might be a good time to add a little recipe to the cookbook or the main docs on how to use this great functionality. I don't want to make a bunch of extra work here, but having appropriate documentation in the docs for new functionality seems to be a problem with yt in general, and this seems to be the only obvious time when it can be added, while it is fresh in the developer's mind. Again, I don't want to raise the effort required to contribute, but the alternative is out-of-date documentation...

Thoughts?

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw: I think this is reasonable.  I think one possibility, which would be perhaps *the* minimum overhead, would be to make the testing script that a developer uses become a cookbook recipe.  This could be as simple as checking it into the documentation repository in the right directory and adding it to a `.rst` file.
content.html: I think this is reasonable. I think one possibility, which would be perhaps the minimum overhead, would be to make the testing script that a developer uses become a cookbook recipe. This could be as simple as checking it into the documentation repository in the right directory and adding it to a .rst file.

content.raw: Seems like the best way is to make sure the docstrings are accurate (IMO).  Cookbooks are much more likely to get out of date as API changes.  A simple unit test using a fake pf seems best for this case.  I can work on such unit tests for the renderer in general, but this won't be possible in the immediate future (and it would be nice to be able to reply to the user email).

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw:
Perhaps here is not the right place to get into this, but I still think that we should write cookbook entries at some point for new functionality, and it seems to me that the best time is when the new functionality gets developed (before the devs forget about it).  Yes, docstrings are good, but most of the users of yt are not looking at source, they just want to look in the docs to see how to do something or to even learn if the functionality exists to do cool things like this.  If no entries exist in the docs, it forces people to the mailing list and irc to even find out what can be done / how to do it.

So, as I say, I don't want to hold up this bit of functionality, because I think it is cool, useful and timely (great response time, Sam).  I just think we need to rethink how best to get docs which reflect the current state of the code.  It's easy (and common) for them to get deprecated or miss cool new functionality like this.
content.html:
Perhaps here is not the right place to get into this, but I still think that we should write cookbook entries at some point for new functionality, and it seems to me that the best time is when the new functionality gets developed (before the devs forget about it). Yes, docstrings are good, but most of the users of yt are not looking at source, they just want to look in the docs to see how to do something or to even learn if the functionality exists to do cool things like this. If no entries exist in the docs, it forces people to the mailing list and irc to even find out what can be done / how to do it.

So, as I say, I don't want to hold up this bit of functionality, because I think it is cool, useful and timely (great response time, Sam). I just think we need to rethink how best to get docs which reflect the current state of the code. It's easy (and common) for them to get deprecated or miss cool new functionality like this.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw:
I agree with Cameron, this works great.  I just have one comment, which is illustrated with the following example:

I'm using a script based on Cameron's notebook: 

```
#!python

from yt.mods import *

pf = load("/Users/goldbaum/Documents/test/galaxy0030/galaxy0030")

tf = ColorTransferFunction((-28, -24))
tf.add_layers(4, w=0.01)
cam = pf.h.camera([0.5, 0.5, 0.5], [0.5, 1.0, 0.7], 20/pf['kpc'], 512, tf)

im = cam.snapshot()
cam.draw_grids(im,alpha=.4)
write_bitmap(im, 'render_with_grids.png')
```
This produces this image http://i.imgur.com/xAImFUf.png

Basically, I think this looks much better than the default, which draws the grids with alpha=0.1.  I'd suggest changing the default to match the default alpha for the domain boundary.

Ok, long post for a short point, I mainly just wanted to paste my script to play with bitbucket's comment markdown functionality ;)
content.html:
I agree with Cameron, this works great. I just have one comment, which is illustrated with the following example:

I'm using a script based on Cameron's notebook: 

from yt.mods import *

pf = load("/Users/goldbaum/Documents/test/galaxy0030/galaxy0030")

tf = ColorTransferFunction((-28, -24))
tf.add_layers(4, w=0.01)
cam = pf.h.camera([0.5, 0.5, 0.5], [0.5, 1.0, 0.7], 20/pf['kpc'], 512, tf)

im = cam.snapshot()
cam.draw_grids(im,alpha=.4)
write_bitmap(im, 'render_with_grids.png')

This produces this image http://i.imgur.com/xAImFUf.png

Basically, I think this looks much better than the default, which draws the grids with alpha=0.1. I'd suggest changing the default to match the default alpha for the domain boundary.

Ok, long post for a short point, I mainly just wanted to paste my script to play with bitbucket's comment markdown functionality ;)

content.raw:
Cameron, by the same token, do you think anyone is reading the dev docs?

I think it's ok to let documentation slip a bit, so long as we know that we should be writing narrative docs for new functionality before the next release.
content.html:
Cameron, by the same token, do you think anyone is reading the dev docs?

I think it's ok to let documentation slip a bit, so long as we know that we should be writing narrative docs for new functionality before the next release.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw:
Nathan, I imagine that people getting started with developing the code check out the dev docs.  I know I do from time to time to look at the PEP standards.  But I think this is a separate matter.

Still, you make a good point that the narrative docs are more important, and the real time for making those is before a point release.  I just know from experience that this doesn't always happen.  Docs always get left off, and it isn't such a big deal to the primary developers, because we're the ones who wrote it, so we know it and know where to look for stuff.  But for new users who aren't familiar with the code, or what functionality the code has, it can be daunting to get under the hood with grin, grep, find, and decoding all of the yt-isms.  

All I'm asking for is that when cool functionality like this gets added to the code base, that we also create a simple script in the cookbook docs that demonstrates its use.  Basically including the notebook/script that I did in these very comments.  As you can see, even a developer like me can get the syntax wrong (taken from the PR description itself), when trying to use this functionality.

I'm sorry to belabor this point guys.  Sam, the PR is awesome, I just ask that you include a short docstring and a demo script in the cookbook part of the docs.  Then I'm all for accept.  But I think I may be in the minority here for requiring additional docs.
content.html:
Nathan, I imagine that people getting started with developing the code check out the dev docs. I know I do from time to time to look at the PEP standards. But I think this is a separate matter.

Still, you make a good point that the narrative docs are more important, and the real time for making those is before a point release. I just know from experience that this doesn't always happen. Docs always get left off, and it isn't such a big deal to the primary developers, because we're the ones who wrote it, so we know it and know where to look for stuff. But for new users who aren't familiar with the code, or what functionality the code has, it can be daunting to get under the hood with grin, grep, find, and decoding all of the yt-isms.

All I'm asking for is that when cool functionality like this gets added to the code base, that we also create a simple script in the cookbook docs that demonstrates its use. Basically including the notebook/script that I did in these very comments. As you can see, even a developer like me can get the syntax wrong (taken from the PR description itself), when trying to use this functionality.

I'm sorry to belabor this point guys. Sam, the PR is awesome, I just ask that you include a short docstring and a demo script in the cookbook part of the docs. Then I'm all for accept. But I think I may be in the minority here for requiring additional docs.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

content.raw: Personally, I think those grids are way too heavy for the default. I think the purpose of having the underlying grid structure in the image should only be to help guide the eye with regard to resolution. By making the boxes so bright, one significantly obscures the data by creating a very bright signal that clutters the visual field. I think this is the volume rendering equivalent of plots where the graph paper is darker and heavier than the data line plotted on it.
content.html: Personally, I think those grids are way too heavy for the default. I think the purpose of having the underlying grid structure in the image should only be to help guide the eye with regard to resolution. By making the boxes so bright, one significantly obscures the data by creating a very bright signal that clutters the visual field. I think this is the volume rendering equivalent of plots where the graph paper is darker and heavier than the data line plotted on it.

content.html: It is set to 0.3, which is I think a good compromise.

pullrequest.title: Draw domain boundary, and first pass at drawing grids in rendering.

description:
This adds the following capability:

```
#!python

im = cam.snapshot('normal_render.png')
cam.draw_domain(im, 'render_with_domain_box.png')

```

It also adds a draw_grids() function which draws all the grids using a colormap for each level.  Other tools that come with this include drawing an arbitrary box.

Update #1: Fix for draw_grids(), which was missing an import.

Update #2: Addressed all comments other than testing/cookbook.
